G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the tort occurred within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the incident occurred in Worcester, and Defendant resides or does business here.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: The Defendant, as landlord and caretaker of the three‑unit apartment building at 123 Maple Street, had a duty to maintain the premises and adjoining sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable steps to remove or treat accumulations of snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that Massachusetts property owners, including landlords, owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain their property, including areas affected by snow and ice, in a reasonably safe condition. The Court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and expressly states that this reasonable‑care duty applies to hazards from snow and ice on premises and approaches, with the scope of reasonable snow and ice removal varying by context (e.g., single‑family home, apartment house, store). That directly supports the proposition that a landlord/caretaker must take reasonable steps to maintain the premises and adjoining walkways, including removing or treating snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.… [W]hat constitutes reasonable snow removal may vary among them.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.proposition: The Defendant, as landlord and caretaker of the three‑unit apartment building at 123 Maple Street, had a duty to maintain the premises and adjoining sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable steps to remove or treat accumulations of snow and ice.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a retired police officer’s right to reinstatement under Massachusetts public employee retirement and civil service statutes. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, premises liability, or any duty to maintain property, including sidewalks or snow and ice removal. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that a landlord at 123 Maple Street had a duty to maintain the premises and adjoining sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition or to remove snow and ice.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, a twenty-year retiree of the Brookline police department (department), raises two issues through his petition for reinstatement: first, what standard should apply in evaluating a retiree’s fitness to return to full employment; and second, whether a long-term retiree must complete retraining before becoming entitled to reinstatement. To answer these questions this court must interpret G. L. c. 32, § 8 (2), and G. L. c. 31, § 39.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known of the dangerous condition given prior warnings from tenants and the foreseeable refreezing.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s knowledge of a dangerous icy condition due to prior tenant warnings and foreseeable refreezing. Dos Santos instead involves a landlord who affirmatively created and maintained a hazardous trampoline–pool setup and knew it was being used dangerously; there is no discussion of snow, ice, refreezing, or tenant complaints about a recurring condition. While the case does discuss foreseeability and a duty to remedy an obvious danger the owner knows people will encounter, it does not address prior tenant warnings or refreezing, so it does not specifically support that proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool, with a ladder leading directly from the pool to the trampoline, for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. He knew that the pool warned against jumping of any kind, and he knew that the setup was dangerous but proceeded with the setup because he thought it would be ‘fun.’ … The defendants knew that it was unsafe to do so and, therefore, could or should have anticipated injuries resulting from this activity.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant’s failure to treat or otherwise make safe the icy walkway constituted a breach of her duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion focused on rejecting rigid entrant classifications (invitee/licensee/trespasser) and discussing the proper framework for premises liability. It does not address icy walkways, snow and ice treatment, or any specific breach involving failure to treat or make safe an icy walkway. Therefore, this excerpt does not provide authority that the defendant’s failure to treat an icy walkway constituted a breach of the duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligent failure to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence rejects the idea that the defendant’s conduct created an unreasonable risk or that plaintiff’s injuries were a legally cognizable, foreseeable result of any negligence. Justice Wilkins emphasizes that the risk of injury from another vehicle’s negligent operation was inherent and obvious and that there was no duty to warn, implying no negligent failure to maintain a reasonably safe condition. Thus, the opinion undercuts, rather than supports, the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were the direct and foreseeable result of defendant’s negligence.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The question is whether, as a matter of law, Arco’s failure to erect a sign warning customers to be on guard against other vehicles did not unreasonably increase the risk of injury caused by the improper operation of other vehicles on the premises. I agree with the court that the evidence did not present a jury question. … In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners and those in control of premises owe all lawful entrants a duty to act with reasonable care to maintain the property in a safe condition and to remedy or warn of dangerous conditions of which they know or reasonably should know.

Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..raw_text: Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372 (1980)
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners and those in control of premises owe all lawful entrants a duty to act with reasonable care to maintain the property in a safe condition and to remedy or warn of dangerous conditions of which they know or reasonably should know.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Boston Edison’s duty as designer/owner of a streetlight pole to design against foreseeable vehicular impacts and protect pedestrians. It analyzes product/design negligence and causation, not the general premises-liability duty of property owners or those in control of premises toward all lawful entrants. The court’s articulated duty is specific to designing and maintaining streetlight poles to avoid unreasonable risks, and the case does not discuss the general obligation to maintain premises in a safe condition or to remedy/warn of dangerous conditions for lawful entrants.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt: [T]he judge charged that Edison had a duty “to install or to maintain or use electric light poles in such a manner and of such a design or composition that they will not create an unreasonable risk of injury to people who are lawfully using the streets and the sidewalks.” It had to provide a reasonably safe — not absolutely safe — pole. In deciding whether Edison had done so, the jury could look to the foreseeable risk of injury to pedestrians when the pole was struck a blow, the technology available at the time, and possibilities and consequences of strengthening the pole.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with whether the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care in storing firearms and reverses summary judgment solely on the existence of that duty. It expressly notes that breach, causation (including proximate cause), and damages are for the jury and does not hold that the defendant’s acts or omissions were the direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injuries. Thus, the case supports a duty-of-care proposition, not the asserted proximate-cause conclusion.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The case holds that the plaintiffs failed to produce any evidence that the defendant’s acts or omissions caused the scaffolding collapse or their injuries, and therefore could not establish causation—an essential element of negligence. Rather than finding that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the fall, the court affirms summary judgment precisely because such a causal link was missing. Thus, the opinion contradicts, rather than supports, the claimed proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs… bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… These unsubstantiated conjectures cannot support any claim that some property defect chargeable to the defendant caused (or even contributed) to the collapse of the scaffolding.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60F, Plaintiff seeks compensation for all damages allowed by law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award costs and interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 39.raw_text: Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 398 (2013)
Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 39.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all compensatory damages available under Massachusetts law.
Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 39.case_name: Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc.
Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 39.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the jury’s award of compensatory and punitive damages in a wrongful death/products liability case, but it does not articulate any general rule about a plaintiff’s entitlement to or ability to seek "all compensatory damages available under Massachusetts law." It simply describes the specific damages awarded (fair monetary value, conscious pain and suffering, and punitive damages) without setting out a broad principle about the full scope of compensatory damages in Massachusetts. Therefore, it does not meaningfully support the claimed proposition.
Aleo v. SLB Toys USA, Inc., 466 Mass. 39.relevant_excerpt: “A Superior Court jury found Toys R Us liable for negligence, breach of warranty, and wrongful death, awarding compensatory damages in the amount of $2,640,000. The compensatory damages comprised $2,540,000 for the ‘fair monetary value’ of Robin to Michael and to the couple’s daughter, plus $100,000 for Robin’s conscious pain and suffering. The jury also found Toys R Us grossly negligent and awarded punitive damages in the amount of $18 million.”

Guinan v. Boston College, 451 Mass. 437.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all compensatory damages available under Massachusetts law.
Guinan v. Boston College, 451 Mass. 437.support_reasoning: The opinion in Guinan v. Boston College (actually Commonwealth v. Lora, 451 Mass. 425 (2008), within the provided text) deals entirely with criminal procedure—specifically, racial profiling, selective enforcement, and the exclusionary rule in the context of a motion to suppress. It does not address civil remedies, compensatory damages, or the scope of damages available under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a plaintiff seeks all compensatory damages available under Massachusetts law.
Guinan v. Boston College, 451 Mass. 437.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the application of the exclusionary rule to evidence obtained in violation of the constitutional right to the equal protection of the laws is entirely consistent with the policy underlying the exclusionary rule, is properly gauged to deter intentional unconstitutional behavior, and furthers the protections guaranteed by the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights.
